title: Turrets
name: Turrets
description:
Every one third of a Roman Mile (1667 Rfeet or 493m) between the Milecastles a turret was located (thus there were two turrets between a pair of milecastles). These are traditionally numbered according to the Wall Mile and then distinguished with a letter 'a' or 'b' and many also have a name relating to a nearby landmark. Some turrets have not been located and their positions are traditionally estimated from known structures.
Turrets could have an entrance on the western or eastern side of the south-facing wall and the curtain wall could either be bonded with them (stone wall turrets) or butt up against them (turf wall turrets). Some turrets in the eastern sector were built to the broad gauge with short 'wing walls' which were preserved when the narrower curtain wall was eventually constructed around them.
Handbook pp.68–72
